cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to film form (including style and narration), different types of films, and popular approaches to the study of cinema. Topics include: narrative cinema, documentary, avant-garde, genre, authorship, ideology, and representation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Film Study

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Introduction to Film Study students must also enrol in a TUT section.

Delivery Instructions

Both lectures and screenings are delivered online and asynchronous. Tutorials are delivered online and synchronous, as per the meeting schedule. Students need access to high-speed internet service and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate on Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Films create story worlds, imaginary environments in which characters live and act, and where events, large and small, transpire. Some story worlds are elaborate, fanciful constructs (think of Disney’s animated films). Others stay close to reality (think of “docudramas”). But across the spectrum, all of them are framed by and provided with rules of time and space, of believable or impossible. This course offers an examination of selected story worlds from several periods of film history. Emphasis falls on the expansive story worlds of contemporary corporately-run media-franchise “universes,” like the cross-media “DC Universe.” Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Story Worlds and the Cinema

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Seminar style course to be live-streamed permitting synchronous online participation. Students accessing remotely need a webcam, microphone, internet, and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate on Quercus.

courses.name: Film Cultures I: Art and Industry

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the practices, theories, and debates surrounding the emergence of cinema through to the development of studio system filmmaking in the first half of the 20th Century. Topics include: film's relation to the other arts, formalist and realist traditions, technological innovations, audiences and reception, and cultural industries.
cmCourseInfo.title: Film Cultures I: Art and Industry

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are delivered in person, live-streamed, and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery both in person and online, but also asynchronous online attendance). Screenings are delivered online and in an asynchronous manner. Tutorials are delivered synchronously online, as per the meeting schedule. Students accessing remotely need access to high-speed internet service and the ability to access Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Horror film as a genre, focusing on three types of international horror: the un-dead, body horror, and the supernatural. The genre's popular appeal, affective power, unique means of producing pleasure, and current global resurgence will be emphasized. Topics include: the aesthetics of gore and violence, technologies of fear, J-Horror, new French extremity, cult fandom and paracinema, and media convergence.
cmCourseInfo.title: Horror Film

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered asynchronously online (recorded) and tutorials will be delivered synchronously online, per the meeting schedule. Screenings will be online and asynchronous, but will be coordinated with lectures (meaning students will be responsible for viewing films in the order outlined on the syllabus and in a timely manner). Students need internet access with speeds that facilitate streaming and video conferencing, access to a web camera and microphone, and the ability to use to use several functions within Quercus (Discussion Boards, Teams, etc.).

cmCourseInfo.description: Action movies cement the dominance of commercial cinema, and they largely define the contemporary era of the blockbuster and CGI effects. This course examines the narrative modes and the extremes that action scenes reach, and it explores the commercial and social function of the genre. The course also traces Action's historic reach and global diversity to include its significant precursors and transnational forms that Action cinema takes on.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cinema and Sensation I: Action/Spectacle

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Tutorials are online synchronous and will meet as scheduled. Students need internet access, webcam, microphone, and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate on Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Erotic images and sounds have long featured in filmic pleasure and, for just as long, excited controversy. This course examines how sex is articulated on screen and how its regulation suggests broader themes and ideas. Topics include: obscenity laws and the history of film censorship, the eroticized aspects of conventional movies, art cinema, and "adult" erotic films.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cinema and Sensation II: Sex

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Tutorials are online synchronous and will meet as scheduled. Students need internet access, webcam, microphone, and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate on Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description:
Examines cinema as a commercial enterprise, emphasizing production, distribution, and exhibition and the political economy of North American film culture.

This is a Breadth Category 3 course but has been specially-designed to fulfill the Quantitative Reasoning requirement for Cinema Studies Specialists and Majors.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Business of Film

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures to be delivered online synchronously per meeting schedule. Screenings will be online and asynchronous. Students will need access to high-speed internet and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Aug 18, 2020: Section cancelled

notes.name: Section Note

cmCourseInfo.description: Course on special topics in Cinema Studies. Topics vary each year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Cinema Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online asynchronously. Screenings and introduction to film will be delivered synchronously using BB Collaborate on Quercus. Screenings and introductions will also be recorded and made available for students who are unable to view at the allotted screening time. The live screening attendance will optional on the syllabus. Tutorials will be delivered online synchronously using BB Collaborate. Students need a computer with Internet access and a webcam, the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate on Quercus.

courses.name: Film Cultures II: Politics and Global Media

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines film theory and practice from the 1950s onward, and the impact of media change on earlier film cultures and aesthetics. Topics include: New Wave cinemas, the politicization of theory, spectatorship, counter-cinemas, transnational film and “Global Hollywood”, and media theory from the analog to the digital.
cmCourseInfo.title: Film Cultures II: Politics and Global Media

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Contact hours: 2.0 hrs/week of lecture, 2.0 hrs/week of screenings (4.0 total)

Recordings of lectures and all film screenings will be available for students to view asynchronously. 

Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. 

It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Special Topics in Genre and Modes

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "Contemporary Screen Comedy," and "Eco-cinema: The Nature of Film."
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Genre and Modes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Weekly screenings will be online and asynchronous via MyMedia. Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. Discussions are delivered online per the meeting schedule (6-8PM Tuesdays) and will be recorded and shared. Learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Students will need to familiarize themselves with Powerpoint or Keynote to produce presentations. They will need to use several functions within Quercus (Discussion Boards, BB Collaborate), and they will need to be prepared to interact via MSTeams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "Contemporary Screen Comedy," and "Eco-cinema: The Nature of Film."

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are delivered online synchronously. Screenings are asynchronous. Students need access to high-speed internet service and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and/or ZOOM.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines "cult" and "exploitation" cinema. It examines the growing popularity of cult/exploitation films as an emerging cinematic subculture that valorizes disreputable or "trash" cinema. A number of sub-genres within exploitation film, including teen films, educational/instructional films, sexploitation, and Blaxploitation, will be explored. The social politics of appropriating texts through ironic reading strategies will also be considered.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cult Cinema

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule, and recorded to allow for asynchronous delivery. Students need internet connection and access to Blackboard Collaborate for discussions through Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on queer film, television, and/or digital media. Approaches may include cultural, historical, analytical, critical, and theoretical methods. This course may focus on the representation of queer people in film in media, or film and/or media made by queer people, or both.
cmCourseInfo.title: Queer Film and Media
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: CIN105Y1, or 1.0 FCE from SDS255H1, SDS256H1, SDS279H1, SDS355H1

notes.name: Course Note

Weekly screenings will be online and asynchronous (with a recorded introduction), but these will be coordinated with lectures and a synchronous, live-streamed discussion as per the meeting schedule. An alternate form of participation will be provided for students who cannot attend the scheduled session. Students need high-speed internet for streaming and video conferencing, access to a web camera and microphone, and the ability to use functions within Quercus (Discussion Boards, BB Collaborate, etc.).

courses.name: American Filmmaking in the Studio Era

cmCourseInfo.description: Industrial, economic, ideological, and aesthetic dimensions of the American studio era.
cmCourseInfo.title: American Filmmaking in the Studio Era

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are delivered online, live-streamed and recorded permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance. Students need internet connection, access to a web camera, and microphone for participation in Blackboard Collaborate discussions through Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examination of Chinese films in their three post-World War II production centres: The People's Republic of China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. Commercial, political, and aesthetic trends; international reception; major auteurs and genres. Directors include Tsui Hark, Chen Kaige, Zang Yimou, Edward Yang, John Woo, and Wong Kar-Wai.
cmCourseInfo.title: Chinese Cinemas

notes.content:
